node.title: Former NFL star Demaryius Thomas dead at 33
node.description: He finished his 10-year career as one of the most productive wide receivers of his time, a five-time Pro Bowler and the top pass-catcher for the Denver Broncos' 2015 Super Bowl championship team.
node.content: ["Former NFL star Demaryius Thomas was found dead in his Roswell, Georgia home Thursday evening, police there say. He was 33.", "\"Preliminary information is that his death stems from a medical issue, and our investigators currently have no reason to believe otherwise,\" police said in a statement.", "CBSSports.com's Cody Benjamin reports that Thomas, who last played in 2019, had only officially announced his retirement in June.", "He finished his 10-year career as one of the most productive wide receivers of his time, most notably as a five-time Pro Bowler and the No. 1 pass-catcher for Denver's 2015\u00a0Super Bowl\u00a0championship team.", "Drafted 22nd overall by the Broncos out of Georgia Tech in 2010, Thomas spent more than eight seasons in Denver, finishing as one of the franchise's best receivers. He ranks second among all-time Broncos in career receiving yards and touchdowns, and third in career catches.", "Rest in peace, Bay Bay \ud83d\udc94 pic.twitter.com/1Qqa1fiYWo", "Thomas had five straight 1,000-yard seasons from 2012-2016 -- four of them with more than 1,300 yards. He ranks 54th among all-time\u00a0NFL\u00a0players in career receiving yardage (9,763).", "He's perhaps best known for his starring role as Peyton Manning's top target during the Broncos' bid for several titles in the 2010s. Thomas hauled in 28 passes for 306 yards and three touchdowns during Denver's 2013 postseason alone, helping the team advance to Super Bowl XLVIII. Two years later, he topped 100 catches for a second straight season while helping the Broncos claim their first title in nearly two decades.", "Thomas was traded from the Broncos to the\u00a0Texans\u00a0in October 2018, during his eighth year in Denver, and played seven games with Houston before signing with the New York Jets in 2019. He played 11 games in New York during his final season, totaling 36 catches for 433 yards, then announced his retirement two years later.", "For Breaking News & Analysis Download the Free CBS News app"]
